Graphic lit notes

Notes on my growing collection of graphic novels. Many are memoirs. Most are considered radical.

Barefoot Gen: A Cartoon Story of Hiroshima, by Keiji Nakazawa

Read: 10/2023, Published: 1972

Shubeik Lubeik, by Deena Mohamed

Read: 6/2023, Published: 1/2023

The Great American Dust Bowl, by Don Brown

Read: 5/2023, Published: 2013

Hidden Systems, by Dan Nott

Read: 10/2023, Published: 2023

The High Desert: Black. Punk. Nowhere., by James Spooner

Read: 10/2022, Published: 2022

Ginseng Roots comic series 1-12, by Craig Thompson

Read: 2023, Published: 2020

Barefoot Gen Volume 2: The Day After, by Keiji Nakazawa

Read: 2023, Published: 1973

Red Rosa: A Graphic Biography of Rosa Luxemburg, by Kate Evans

Read: 2022, Published: 2015

Not the Israel My Parents Promised Me, by Harvey Pekar

Read: 2023, Published: 2014

Ducks: Two Years in the Oil Sands, by Kate Beaton

Read: 2022, Published: 2022

Radical: My Year with a Socialist Senator, by Sofia Warren

Read: 2022, Published: 2022

Paying the Land, by Joe Sacco

Read: 2022, Published: 2020

What is Home, Mum?, by Sabba Khan

Read: 2022, Published: 2022

Run: Series Book 1, by John Lewis & Andrew Aydin

Read: 2021, Published: 2021

March: Series 1-3, by John Lewis & Andrew Aydin

Read: 2021, Published: 2016

Persepolis: 1-4, The Story of a Childhood and The Story of a Return, by Marjane Satrapi

Read: 2020, Published: 2003

Blankets, by Craig Thompson

Read: 2020, Published: 2003

Unrig: How to Fix Our Broken Democracy, by World Citizen Comics

Read: 2020, Published: 2020

Oak Flat: A Fight for Sacred Land in the American West, by Lauren Redniss

Read: 2020, Published: 2020

Diary of an Early American Boy, by Eric Sloane

Read: 1958, Published: 1958

Chicken with Plums, by Marjane Satrapi

Read: 2004, Published: 2004

The Most Costly Journey: Stories of Migrant Farmworkers in Vermont Drawn by New England Cartoonists, by Andy Kolovos, Marek Bennett, Julia Grand Doucet

Read: 2021, Published: 2021
